Centroid.title: Centroid
abstract: In centroid-based clustering, clusters are represented by a central vector
This may not necessarily be a member of the data set.
When the number of clusters is fixed to k, k-means clustering gives a formal definition as an optimization problem:
find the  k cluster centers and assign the objects to the nearest cluster center, such that the squared distances from the cluster are minimized
purpose: Known number of clusters, very large samples

KMeans.title: K Means
abstract: A simple iterative method to partition a given dataset into a userspecified number of clusters
purpose: Known number of clusters, very large samples
advantages: Produces tighter clusters than hierarchical clustering
Faster than hierarchical clustering for large number of variables
disadvantages: The greedy-descent nature of k-means on a non-convex cost also implies that the convergence is only to a local optimum
Quite sensitive to the initial centroid locations
Falter whenever the data is not well described by reasonably separated spherical balls
Sensitive to the presence of outliers
applications: Use by major search engine to cluster web pages by similarity and identify the ‘relevance rate’ of search results to reduce access time

SelfOrganizingMaps.title: Self Organizing Maps
purpose: Known number of clusters, very large samples

Affinity.title: Affinity
abstract: clusters data by diffusion in the similarity matrix.
purpose: Many clusters, uneven cluster size, non-flat geometry

FuzzyCMeans.title: Fuzzy C Means
abstract: computes fuzzy membership functions for each clusters rather than a hard one
purpose: Known number of clusters, very large samples

Hierarchial.title: Hierarchial
abstract: a general family of clustering algorithms that build nested clusters by merging them successively.
purpose: Derive an ordered set of cluster with varialbe precision

Ward.title: Ward
abstract: The Ward object performs a hierarchical clustering based on the Ward algorithm, that is a variance-minimizing approach.
At each step, it minimizes the sum of squared differences within all clusters (inertia criterion).
purpose: Derive an ordered set of cluster with varialbe precision

BIRCH.title: Balanced Iterative Reducing and Clustering using Hierarchies
purpose: Derive an ordered set of cluster with varialbe precision

Agglomerative.title: Agglomerative
purpose: Derive an ordered set of cluster with varialbe precision

Canopy.title: Canopy
purpose: Derive an ordered set of cluster with varialbe precision

Fractal.title: Fractal
purpose: Derive an ordered set of cluster with varialbe precision

Spectral.title: Spectral
abstract: does a low-dimension embedding of the affinity matrix between samples, followed by a KMeans in the low dimensional space.
purpose: Few clusters, even cluster size, non-flat geometry

GaussianMixture.title: Gaussian Mixture
abstract: Each cluster is described in terms of a Gaussian density, which has a centroid (as in K-means), and a covariance matrix.
advantages: Speed:: It is the fastest algorithm for learning mixture models
Agnostic:: This algorithm maximizes only the likelihood, it will not bias the means towards zero, or bias the cluster sizes to have specific structures that might or might not apply.
disadvantages: Singularities:: when one has insufficiently many points per mixture, estimating the covariance matrices becomes difficult, and the algorithm is known to diverge and find solutions with infinite likelihood unless one regularizes the covariances artificially.

Number of Components:: this algorithm will always use all the components it has access to, needing heldout data or information theoretical criteria to decide how many components to use in the absence of external cues.

DBSCAN.title: DBSCAN
abstract: The DBSCAN algorithm clusters data by finding core points which have many neighbours within a given radius.
After a core point is found, the cluster is expanded by adding its neighbours to the current cluster
and recursively checking if any are core points. Formally, a point is considered a core point
if it has more than min_points points which are of a similarity greater than the given threshold eps.
The algorithm can detect outliers which  are defined as points which do not belong to any current cluster
and donot have enough close neighbours to start a new cluster.

MeanShift.title: Mean Shift
abstract: clusters data by estimating blobs in a smooth density of points matrix.
purpose: Many clusters, uneven cluster size, non-flat geometry
